items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 04:15 on 17/11/23, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 207 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next several days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/23, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible early on Thursday morning. 
Widespread heavy rainfall is forecast overnight across Devon. This will cause rivers in the area to rise.  
The main areas of concern are Dartmeet, Ashburton, Buckfastleigh, Totnes, Brixham, Torquay and Paignton. River levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers.
We expect rivers to remain high throughout Thursday. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Thursday evening or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent rainfall associated with Storm Debi. Flooding is expected along riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. The River Ouse is falling slowly and is expected to continue falling this evening, Thursday 16/11/23. Further showers are expected over the next few days. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. This message will be updated by 11pm on 16/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. Over the next week, tide levels are forecast to be lower than today (16/11/2023), and we are not expecting further flood impacts as a result. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

The Flood Alert has now been removed. 
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

The unsettled weather which elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. However, water flow in the River Itchen remains high, and the river will continue to be vulnerable to further rain. Levels may continue to be high, especially around the times of high tide, but only very minor impacts, if any, are anticipated. We do not expect impacts to major roads or property. We continue to monitor the forecast and may issue further advice if flooding is expected to occur.

items.message: A high tide of 4.61 mAOD is expected at Richmond at 04:30 am on Friday 17th November. Due to high river flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates will not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tide will flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the river flow already in the channel, will push water levels higher. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is expected around 04:00 am to 05:00 am tomorrow, Friday 17th November, although we do not expect any flooding to buildings. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.

Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.message:
Following a band of rainfall over Wednesday night and into Thursday morning, the River Tone at Bishops Hull and the Halsewater Stream are rising, and this Flood Alert has been issued. The flooding of low-lying land near the River Tone and the Halsewater Stream is possible from midday today, Thursday 16/11/2023. No property flooding is expected. 
Unsettled weather will continue with possible showers during Thursday and Friday before a band of more sustained rainfall over Friday night and into Saturday. 
We will continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels in the River Tone and tributaries. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on 17/11/2023.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message: This flood alert has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.34 m and slowly rising. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.46 m and is steady. 
The band of rainfall has now passed out of the area, but showers are still possible. Unsettled weather will continue, and a further band of rainfall is currently forecast to arrive Friday evening and into Saturday. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. 
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elson’s Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on Friday 17 November.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Actual peak:-  Llanymynech 4.3m on Tuesday afternoon, 14/11/23.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 16 November. Water levels continue to remain high and may last for the next few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system combined with the recent rainfall across the area. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The weather forecast is for rain later on today, Thursday 16 November. Tomorrow is expected to be dry with further rain forecast for the weekend.  Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths.  We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message on Friday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Thursday 16 November. River levels remain higher than normal after the rainfall yesterday.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas around Diss, Eye, Harleston and Bungay. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Thursday 16 November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day but further rain is forecast for this weekend some of which could be heavy. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Friday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

River levels in Hellingly and Alfriston are slowly starting to rise following 10mm of rainfall this morning (Thursday 16/11/2023). Rain should clear by late afternoon. The river should peak by about 01:00 on Friday 17/11/2023 in Hellingly, and 13:00 on Friday 17/11/2023 in Alfriston. Only minimal flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads are currently expected in both Hellingly and Alfriston. Friday is expected to remain dry. However, more rain (20-25mm) is forecast for Saturday (18/11/2023). The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers will rise again. Property flooding could be possible in both Hellingly and Alfriston on Saturday afternoon, if the maximum rainfall forecast occurs. In Alfriston, the river could remain higher than normal all week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 17/11/2023.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Mythe Bridge and Upper Pond Tewkesbury river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.2m to 3.7m Friday afternoon 17/11/23, Haw Bridge 4.1m to 4.6m Friday afternoon 17/11/23, Upper Pond Tewkesbury 3.2m to 3.70m Friday afternoon 17/11/23.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 9am Friday 17/11/23 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This information is correct as of 17:00 on Thursday 16 November 2023. 
The causeway at Sutton Gault has 7 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency is liaising with Cambridge Highways who will decide whether to close the road.
Rainfall today is less than expected. As such, we expect to see levels begin to fall at Sutton Gault tomorrow. However, levels are slowly rising at Welney causeway, which we will continue to monitor. There are no issues on the Earith causeway. 
We will update this message by 09:00 on Friday 17 November 2023.

River levels remain high on the River Ouse in response to recent heavy rainfall in the upper catchments associated with Storm Debi. Levels in York at the Viking recorder are around 4m and are expected to continue falling this evening, Thursday 16/11/23. The current level at Naburn is 3.37m. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.  The Foss Barrier is in operation. Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Further showers are expected over the next few days. This message will be updated by 11pm on 16/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother remains high, but is falling in Fittleworth. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads will continue in Fittleworth. Rain today (16/11/2023) has now cleared. Only 10mm has been measured. The Western Rother will rise a small amount in all communities, but minor flood impacts are only expected in Fittleworth. Friday (17/11/2023) is expected to remain dry. River levels should fall all along the Western Rother, although it is possible river levels in Fittleworth may rise a small amount on Friday. More rain (20-25mm) is forecast for Saturday (18/11/2023). The Western Rother will rise again. It is currently thought flood impacts will remain minor, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads. However, from Saturday afternoon, flood water could potentially approach properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. River levels in Fittleworth could be higher than normal all week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 17/11/2023.

items.message: However, further organised bands of rain are forecast on the evening of Friday 17th of November, and into Saturday morning. This may cause rivers to rise again. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

The actual rainfall over last night was less than forecast and the River Isle and River Parrett have only just started to rise in response. Whilst the band of rainfall will pass out of the area during Thursday morning, further showers are possible. This Flood Alert remains in force whilst we continue to monitor the rainfall and river levels. 
The flooding of low-lying land remains possible and areas most at risk include roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges.
The unsettled weather continues, and a further band of rainfall is currently forecast to arrive Friday evening and into Saturday. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 17/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride.
Further light rainfall is forecast from Friday.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 16/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and slowly rising. Flooding is still affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The Aldingbourne Rife will continue rising today, before starting to slowly fall on Friday (17/11/2023). The Barnham Rife should slowly fall from 15:00 today. Rain should clear by late afternoon. Friday (17/11/2023) will be dry. However, more rain (20-25mm) is forecast for Saturday (18/11/2023). The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes will rise again on Saturday morning. Flooding will continue in Bersted. Isolated property flooding could be possible in Barnham on Saturday morning. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 17/11/2023.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 8.0 m and steady. The drain level at HEPS is 7.79 m and steady.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
The band of rainfall has now passed out of the area, but showers are still possible. Unsettled weather will continue, and a further band of rainfall is currently forecast to arrive Friday evening and into Saturday. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. When river levels allow, pumping continues at Huish Episcopi and we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to evacuate water.
Please consider local water levels and weather conditions and do not walk or drive through flood water.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the Drain at Huish Episcopi pumping station please refer to our website: Check For Flooding (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).
This message will be updated by 1pm on 17/11/2023.

The Combe Haven in Bulverhythe is high and rising, and will continue to rise by 30cm over each high tide (roughly at 11:00 and 23:00 each day). Flooding will continue to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and possibly some gardens on Bexhill Road in Bulverhythe. The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst is also rising, but is not expected to get as high as Tuesday this week. Only minimal flood impacts are expected today (16/11/2023) in Crowhurst. The peak levels in Bulverhythe today and Friday (17/11/2023) are not expected to be higher than Wednesday. Rain will clear by late afternoon. Friday is expected to remain dry. However, more rain (20-25mm) is forecast for Saturday (18/11/2023). The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven will rise again on Saturday, and property flooding could be possible on Saturday afternoon. The river will be sensitive to any additional rainfall over the rest of winter. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 17/11/2023.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and slowly rising. Flooding is still affecting the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, some areas of Durban Road, fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and land and caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Rainfall this morning (Thursday 16/11/2023) is causing river levels to rise again by a small amount, which will continue into this evening, before starting to slowly fall on Friday (17/11/2023). Rain should clear by late afternoon today. Tomorrow (Friday 17/11/2023) is expected to remain dry. However, more rain (20-25mm) is forecast for Saturday (18/11/2023). The Aldingbourne Rife could rise by about 25cm on Saturday. With the rest of November forecast to remain unsettled, the Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 on 17/11/2023.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

River flows are steady however high tides are expected to raise river levels on the River Thames in the Trowlock area. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 04:30 on 17/11/23 and is forecast to reach approximately 5.05m. The following high tide is expected at 17:15 on 17/11/23 and is forecast to reach approximately 5.05m. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 17/11/23 or if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels continue to remain high due to today’s heavy rainfall. Minor and localised flooding may be possible on the next high tide. River levels at Grove Ferry are expected to peak around 03:00 on Friday 17 November 2023. Flooding of properties is not expected. Weather conditions remain unsettled over the next couple of days, with further heavy rainfall forecast for Saturday 18 November. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We will review this message by 09:00 on Friday 17 November with the view of removing this message.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 17/11/23 or if the situation changes.

River levels have risen in response to the recent rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high during the evening of Thursday 16th November and possibly the early hours of Friday 17th November. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.   

Further organised bands of rain are forecast on the evening of Friday 17th of November, and into Saturday morning, which may cause rivers to rise again.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: The flood alert for the River Hull Central catchment remains in place. River levels are still rising in response to recent rainfall associated with Storm Debi. Areas most at risk include the central River Hull area including Arram, Tickton, Beverley and Dunswell. Further rain is forecast at the weekend and we will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Thursday 16 November. River levels remain higher than normal after recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet. The forecast is for further rain this afternoon and evening, Thursday 16 November. Tomorrow is due to be a dryer day but further rain is forecast for this weekend, some of which could be heavy.  Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Friday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are steady but high on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue. It is forecast to be mainly dry overnight 16/11/23, with the possibility of some showery rain. We expect river levels to begin to slowly fall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning 17/11/23, or if the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.34 m and slowly rising. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 5.46 m and is steady. 
The band of rainfall has now passed out of the area, but showers are still possible. Unsettled weather will continue, and a further band of rainfall is currently forecast to arrive Friday evening and into Saturday. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. 
We are pumping at Currymoor and Saltmoor pumping stations when river levels allow and have deployed additional temporary pumps at both stations and at Elson’s Clyce. The Parrett Relief Channel is being used to evacuate the water away.
Please consider weather conditions, local water levels and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated before 1pm on Friday 17 November.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: A gradual easing of conditions over the past week is likely to be reversed following a fresh band of heavy rain in the next 24 hours. We do not expect property flooding at this stage, but some roads, including from Winterborne Abbas to Winterborne Came are likely to be flooded once more. Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. EA staff will continue to monitor the situation locally and will update this message should the situation change.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. No rainfall is forecast today 11/11/23, but heavy rainfall is expected overnight on Sunday into Monday, with the weather becoming more settled later in the week.
Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 18/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Piddle.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham from 09:00 AM on 13/11/2023.

Avoid driving through flood water if at all possible as your bow wave can cause damage to nearby homes. Water levels in the Wallop Brook are now falling. Small amounts of rain (12mm) are forecast over the next 48 hours. This may cause a minor increase in water levels, but we do not expect it to cause a significant impact. From Sunday (19/11/2023) onwards, the weather is then relatively dry, which will allow water levels to return to normal. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. We will issue further advice if additional rainfall causes a significant rise in water levels.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are steady on the River Leach as a result of previous heavy rainfall. Showers are expected this morning and overnight (16/11/23) with further unsettled weather over the coming week. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.message: This flood warning has been removed as river levels have fallen back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary.

River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York due to rainfall in the upper catchment as a result of Storm Debi. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties along Intake Lane, Mill Lane, Yew Tree Close, Darling Lane and Hauling Lane. The level in York at the Viking recorder is around 4m and is expected to continue falling this evening, Thursday 16/11/23. Further showers are forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast. The Foss Barrier is being operated. Please put your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 11pm on 16/11/2023, or as the situation changes.
